#define SYSCALL_ALLOCATE   (8)

System call that allocates a memory block.

The length of the requested memory block is passed in rdi. Allocation flags for the block is passed in rsi. The system call returns the address or an error code.

Definition at line 58 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by alloc().

#define SYSCALL_ALLOCATEPORT   (10)

System call that allocates a port.

The identity number of the port is passed in rdi. The system call returns a handle to the port or an error code if unsuccessful.

Definition at line 76 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by allocateport().

#define SYSCALL_CONDITIONVARIABLESIGNAL   (25)

Performs a signal operation on a condition variable.

The handle of the condition variable is passed in the rdi register.

The system call returns in rax ALL_OK if successful or an error code if unsuccessful.

Definition at line 198 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by conditionvariablesignal().

#define SYSCALL_CONDITIONVARIABLEWAIT   (24)

Performs a wait operation on a condition variable.

The handle of the condition variable is passed in the rdi register. The handle of the associated mutex is passed in the rsi register.

The system call returns in rax ALL_OK if successful or an error code if unsuccessful.

Definition at line 190 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by conditionvariablewait().

#define SYSCALL_CREATECONDITIONVARIABLE   (21)

Creates a new condition variable and returns if successful the handle of the condition variable in the rax register.

If unsuccessful the system call returns an error code in rax.

Definition at line 165 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by createconditionvariable().

#define SYSCALL_CREATEMUTEX   (20)

Creates a new mutex and returns if successful the handle of the mutex in the rax register.

If unsuccessful the system call returns an error code in rax.

Definition at line 160 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by createmutex().

#define SYSCALL_CREATEPROCESS   (5)

System call that creates a new process with one single thread.

It takes an index into the executable table in rdi. The program used is the executable whose index is passed in rdi.

Definition at line 43 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by createprocess().

#define SYSCALL_CREATESEMAPHORE   (17)

Creates a new semaphore and returns if successful the handle of the semaphore in the rax register.

The initial value of the semaphore count value is passed in the rdi register.

If unsuccessful the system call returns an error code in rax.

Definition at line 139 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by createsemaphore().

#define SYSCALL_CREATETHREAD   (16)

Creates a new thread in the process of the calling thread.

The value of rip register of the new thread is passed in the rdi registe. The value of the rsp register of the new thread is passed in rsi. rflags of the new thread is set to 0x200. The other registers are undefinied.

The system call returns in rax ALL_OK if successful or an error code if unsuccessful.

Definition at line 132 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by createthread().

#define SYSCALL_DEBUGGER   (3)

System call that pauses execution by invoking the bochs debugger.

Definition at line 31 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by debugger().

#define SYSCALL_FINDPORT   (11)

System call that finds a port.

The identity number of the port is passed in rdi. The owning process identity is passed in rsi. The system call returns a handle to the port or an error code if unsuccessful.

Definition at line 82 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by findport().

#define SYSCALL_FREE   (9)

System call that frees a memory block allocated through the allocate system call.

The address of the memory block is passed in rdi. The system call returns ALL_OK if successful or an error code if unsuccessful.

#define SYSCALL_GETSCANCODE   (27)

Returns the next scan code from the keyboard in the rax register.

The system call blocks until data is available.

The system call returns a keyboard scan code in rax if successful or an error code if unsuccessful.

The handle of the mutex is passed in the rdi register.

Performs a mutex unlock operation.

The handle of the mutex is passed in the rdi register.

The system call returns in rax ALL_OK if successful or an error code if unsuccessful.

#define SYSCALL_PAUSE   (6)

System call that blocks the calling thread a number of clocks ticks.

The number of clock ticks is passed in rdi. There are 200 clock ticks per second.

Definition at line 48 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by pause().

#define SYSCALL_PRINTAT   (26)

Prints a string at a specific place on the screen.

The pointer to the string, i.e., the address of the first byte of the string is passed in register rdx. The position on the screen is defined with a row and column pair. The column is passed in register rsi and the row is passed in register rdi.

The system call returns ALL_OK in rax if successful or an error code if unsuccessful.

Definition at line 209 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by printat().

#define SYSCALL_PRINTHEX   (2)

System call that prints a hexadecimal value.

Definition at line 29 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by printhex().

#define SYSCALL_PRINTS   (1)

System call that prints a string.

Definition at line 27 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by prints().

#define SYSCALL_RECEIVE   (14)

System call that receives a message.

The handle of the port on which to receive is passed in rdi. 1 is passed in register rsi if long messages are permitted. Register rbx holds a pointer to a buffer that will hold the received message.

The system call returns ALL_OK if successful or an error code if unsuccessful. Register rsi holds the received message type. Register rdi holds the identity of process from which the message was received.

NOTE: You only need to implement short messages functionality in task 5B. Notification and long messages functionality is implemented in task 5A. The functionality to be implemented in task 5A has a slightly different interface. This interface is described in the instructions.

Definition at line 119 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by receive(), and receive_long().

#define SYSCALL_SEMAPHOREDOWN   (18)

Performs a semaphore down operation.

The handle of the semaphore is passed in the rdi register.

The system call returns in rax ALL_OK if successful or an error code if unsuccessful.

Definition at line 147 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by semaphoredown().

#define SYSCALL_SEMAPHOREUP   (19)

Performs an semaphore up operation.

The handle of the semaphore is passed in the rdi register.

The system call returns in rax ALL_OK if successful or an error code if unsuccessful.

Definition at line 155 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by semaphoreup().

#define SYSCALL_SEND   (12)

System call that sends a message.

The handle of the destination port is passed in rdi. The message type is passed in rsi. A pointer to the message is passed in rbx. The system call returns ALL_OK if successful or an error code if unsuccessful.

There are three defined message types: short messages, long messages and notifications. Short messages are passed in registers. Notifications are single bit messages that will never block. Long messages are partially located in memory.

NOTE: You only need to implement short messages functionality in task 5B. Notification and long messages functionality is implemented in task 5A. The functionality to be implemented in task 5A has a slightly different interface. This interface is described in the instructions.

Definition at line 99 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by send(), send_long(), and send_notification().

#define SYSCALL_TERMINATE   (4)

System call that terminates the currently running thread.

It takes no parameters. Terminates the process when there are no threads left.

Definition at line 37 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by terminate().

#define SYSCALL_TIME   (7)

System call that returns the current system time.

The system time is the number of clock ticks since system start. There are 200 clock ticks per second.

Definition at line 53 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by time().

#define SYSCALL_VERSION   (0)

System call that returns the version of the kernel.
